misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sc.next() reads a complete data entry (such as a full name) as a single unit, regardless of whether it contains spaces.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java's Scanner, the next() method only reads input until it encounters any whitespace delimiter. If a user provided a full name like 'Alice Smith', next() would only capture 'Alice', leaving 'Smith' in the buffer. This would cause the student's parallel array logic to shift out of alignment, as 'Smith' would then be incorrectly read into names[1] instead of the next student's name.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: wrong output or runtime exception (InputMismatchException if the displaced tokens cause sc.nextInt() to attempt reading a non-integer string)

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that the input N will always be at least 1, and that the array will always have an element at index N-1.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student fails to account for the 'empty set' scenario. If the user enters 0 for N, the arrays are initialized with size 0. The sorting loops will correctly skip execution, but line 38 and 39 will attempt to access index -1 (0-1), which results in a crash.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that `names[N - 1]` and `scores_array[N - 1]` will always refer to the “last element”, regardless of what value N has (including 0).
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are 0-indexed and valid indices are `0` through `N-1` only when `N>0`. If `N==0`, then `N-1` is `-1`, and attempting to access `names[-1]` or `scores_array[-1]` throws an `ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException`. The program’s logic implicitly requires `N >= 1` or an explicit guard for `N==0`.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime exception (`ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException`) when `N == 0` (or any case where accessing `N-1` is invalid).
